column2: also known as the "City of Lakes" is a city in the state of Rajasthan in India. It is the historic capital of the kingdom of Mewar in the former Rajputana Agency. It was founded in 1558 by Udai Singh II of the Sisodia clan of Rajput
column3: when he shifted his capital from the city of Chittorgarh to Udaipur after Chittorgarh was besieged by Akbar. It remained as the capital city till 1818 when it became a British princely state

column5: near the Gujarat border. It is surrounded by the Aravali Range
column6: which separates it from the Thar Desert. It is around 660 km from Delhi and approximately 800 km from Mumbai
column7: placed almost in the middle of two major Indian metro cities. Besides

column2: by Maharana Udai Singh II in the fertile circular Girwa Valley to the southwest of Nagda
column3: on the Banas River. The city was established as the new capital of the Mewar kingdom. This area already had a thriving trading town
column5: which had served as the capital of Mewar in the 10th through 12th centuries. The Girwa region was thus already well known to Chittaud rulers who moved to it whenever the vulnerable tableland Chittaurgarh was threatened with enemy attacks. Maharana Udai Singh II
column6: in the wake of 16th-century emergence of artillery warfare
column7: decided during his exile at Kumbhalgarh to move his capital to a more secure location. Ayad was flood-prone
column8: hence he chose the ridge east of Pichola Lake to start his new capital city
column9: where he came upon a hermit while hunting in the foothills of the Aravalli Range. The hermit blessed the king and guided him to build a palace on the spot
column10: assuring him it would be well protected. Udai Singh II consequently established a residence on the site. In November 1567
column11: the Mughal emperor Akbar laid siege to the venerated fort of Chittor. To protect Udaipur from external attacks
column12: Maharana Udai Singh built a six kilometre long city wall
column19: Brahmpole and so on. The area within these walls and gates is still known as the old city or the walled city.

column6: Maharana Mahendra Singh Mewar  is the 76th custodian of the Mewar dynasty.

column1: Udaipur with its lakes lies on the south slope of the Aravalli Range in Rajasthan. The northern part of the district consists generally of elevated plateaus

column3: Hills and dense Forest. There are two important passages in the Aravali ranges viz. Desuri Nal and Saoke which serves as a link between Udaipur and Jodhpur District.The lakes of the city being interconnected form a lake system which supports and sustains the groundwater recharge
column6: industries and is a source of employment through tourism. The lake system has three main lakes in its upper catchment area

column9: is an integral component of the upper Berach basin. The upper Berach basin is a part of the Gangetic river system
column10: wherein the river Berach meets river Ganga through the rivers Banas

column1: Udaipur city has a hot semi-arid climate. The three main seasons
column2: summer
column4: dominate the city of Udaipur. Being located in the desert lands of Rajasthan
column5: the climate and weather of Udaipur is usually hot. The summer season runs from mid-March to June and touches temperature ranging from 23 °C (73 °F) to 44 °C (111 °F) in the months of March to June.  Monsoons arrive in the month of July heralded by dust and thunderstorms. With its greenery and lakes
column6: the city is one of the top monsoon destinations of the country. The winter season prevails from the month of October till the month of March. Humidity
column8: diminishes at the arrival of winters. The city observes pleasant sunny days and enjoyable cool nights with the temperature ranging from 5 °C (41 °F) to 30 °C (86 °F).Udaipur's monsoon and winter climates are the most appealing time to visit. Tourists arrive in large numbers

column1: Ghoomar dance is a part of the royal culture of the Mewar Region of Rajasthan. This is a community dance for women and performed on auspicious occasions where the ladies move gracefully in circles.

column2: one of the most sensuous dance forms of Rajasthan
column3: is performed by the Kalbeliya snake charmers' community with the Sapera dancers wearing long
column4: black skirts embroidered with silver ribbons.

column1: Bhavai dance consists of veiled women dancers balancing up to seven or nine brass pitchers as they dance nimbly
column2: pirouetting and then swaying with the soles of their feet perched on the top of a glass or on the edge of the sword

column1: Kachchhi Ghodi dance is performed on dummy horses where men in elaborate costumes ride the equally well decorated dummy horses. Holding naked swords
column2: these dancers move rhythmically to the beating of drums and fifes.Following a lineage of age-old traditions and adhering to religious significance

column8: that used to echo in the courts of the erstwhile rulers of the state.Miniature paintings are amongst the most famous paintings developed under the patronage of the rulers of Rajasthan. The simplest among these are done on walls

The tradition of painting the wall of houses with scenes from mythological and chivalric tales has been prevalent in Rajasthan for the past many centuries. The people of the city make use of such wall paintings for decorations during wedding celebrations. Noted amongst the miniature style of paintings are particularly the Pichvais
column11: which are those made on cloth

column21: and puppets. With various cultural events including folk song and dance performances

column1: Gangaur is one of the most important local festivals in Rajasthan. In some form or the other it is celebrated all over Rajasthan. "gan" is a synonym for Lord Shiva and "Gauri" or "gaur" stands for Goddess Parvati
column2: the heavenly consort of Lord Shiva. Gangaur celebrates the union of the two and is a symbol of conjugal and marital happiness.

column1: It is celebrated in the month of Chaitra (March–April)
column2: the first month of the Hindu calendar. This month marks the end of winter and the onset of spring.

column1: This festival is celebrated especially by women
column2: who worship clay idols of "Gan" & "Gauri" in their houses. These idols are worshiped by the girls who seek the blessings of Gan and Gauri for a good spouse
column3: while the married women pray for the good health and long life of their husbands.

column1: On the eve of the Gangaur festival
column2: women decorate their palms and fingers with henna.

column1: Udaipur has the privilege of having a dedicated Ghat named after Gangaur. Gangaur Ghat or Gangori Ghat is situated on the waterfront of Lake Pichola. This ghat serves as a prime location for the celebration of multiple festivals
column2: including the Gangaur festival. The idols of Gan and Gauri are immersed in the Lake Pichola from this ghat.
